Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CRIM1010 - Criminology: An Introduction","description":"

Introduces the key concepts and current debates in criminology. Covers basic issues such as the definition, measurement and explanations of crime, societal reactions to crime, criminological theories, the role of research and the influence of criminology on public policy.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CRIM1011 - Introduction to Criminal Justice","description":"

In this course you will be introduced to the institutions and practices of the criminal justice system. As well as considering the operation of various components of the criminal justice system - including the police, courts, and corrections - we will also address new and emerging developments in criminal justice practice, crime prevention, and responses to crime. As such, the course will provide you with a critically reflective and thought-provoking introduction to the criminal justice system, accompanied by a discussion of the key issues that arise in relation to its operation (effectiveness and non-discrimination in practice, and alignment with underlying philosophies of justice) and impact on different individuals and groups in society.

Issues in Policing","description":"

CRIM2014 charts the historical development of policing as a set of social and legal practices and challenges you to consider the factors which continue to shape this development. The course will provide you with a critical understanding of the key practices, processes and institutional structures which shape policing in liberal democracies. It will also challenge preconceptions about policing being merely a response to crime, and get you to think critically about how and why policing is a fundamental aspect of the criminal justice process.

It will also challenge preconceptions about policing being merely a response to crime, and get you to think critically about how and why policing is a fundamental aspect of the criminal justice process.

Subject Area: Criminology 


CRIM2020 introduces you to fundamental aspects of criminal justice and process. Woven through the course is a critical examination of the interaction between the criminal justice system and the criminal law: specifically, that application of the law is shaped by and dependent on decisions made by criminal justice actors including police, prosecutors and judicial officers. Specific areas of focus include: why some activities are criminalised and others not; the use and misuse of discretion; the impact of the reliance on summary justice; the significance of pre-trial processes such as arrest and bail; and the over-representation of Indigenous people and other vulnerable groups.

contentlets.description:
Subject Area: Criminology 

CRIM2020 introduces you to fundamental aspects of criminal justice and process. Woven through the course is a critical examination of the interaction between the criminal justice system and the criminal law: specifically, that application of the law is shaped by and dependent on decisions made by criminal justice actors including police, prosecutors and judicial officers. Specific areas of focus include: why some activities are criminalised and others not; the use and misuse of discretion; the impact of the reliance on summary justice; the significance of pre-trial processes such as arrest and bail; and the over-representation of Indigenous people and other vulnerable groups.

Subject Area: Criminology


Criminal Law and Justice 2 (CRIM2021) builds on the themes introduced in Criminal Law and Justice 1 (CRIM2020). In this course you will examine selected crimes, their legal definition and the policy contexts in which they operate. The legal definition of crime happens formally through the pronouncements of legislatures and courts: but it also happens through the operation of the criminal justice process. In CRIM2020 you will focus on the processes by which police, prosecutors and courts deal with crime. In addition, you will consider further how legal definitions, criminal justice practice and competing policy priorities are interconnected. In particular, you will scrutinize the ways in which laws are applied, and also change over time, in relation to issues such as illicit drugs and assault.

contentlets.description:
Subject Area: Criminology

Criminal Law and Justice 2 (CRIM2021) builds on the themes introduced in Criminal Law and Justice 1 (CRIM2020). In this course you will examine selected crimes, their legal definition and the policy contexts in which they operate. The legal definition of crime happens formally through the pronouncements of legislatures and courts: but it also happens through the operation of the criminal justice process. In CRIM2020 you will focus on the processes by which police, prosecutors and courts deal with crime. In addition, you will consider further how legal definitions, criminal justice practice and competing policy priorities are interconnected. In particular, you will scrutinize the ways in which laws are applied, and also change over time, in relation to issues such as illicit drugs and assault.
contentlets.title: Criminal Law and Justice 2

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CRIM2031","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CRIM2031 - Indigenous Perspective in Criminal Justice","description":"

This course traces the use of the criminal justice system in Australia to control Aboriginal people, from the period of colonial dispossession to contemporary times. Looking at crime and criminal justice through a post-colonial lens, we will hear from Aboriginal voices about experiences of crime and criminal justice, identify emerging trends in Indigenous justice from Australia and elsewhere, and consider the possible role of self determination and reconciliation in the 'decolonisation' of criminal justice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bb77c937db791c50eb6b147a3a961923","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Length: 1,200 words +/- 10%

Description:

Select a film, novel, biography or television miniseries which has a credible claim to have been presented from an Indigenous perspective.  Write an essay about Indigenous peoples’ interaction with criminal law and the criminal justice system, using the work as your primary source. You will receive written feedback within two weeks of submission.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3777c937db791c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27778937db791c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Word Length: 500 words +/- 10%

Description:

For the first five weeks of the semester, you must write a 500 word reflective journal about your own learning and insights in understanding Indigenous perspectives on crime and the criminal justice system. Each entry will be peer-reviewed in class, before you select one weekly entry to be submitted for formal assessment.

You will receive written feedback within two weeks of submission.

  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7377c937db791c50eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b3778937db791c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"eb778937db791c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Policy Evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

Length: 2,000 words

Description: 

The 2007 Northern Territory Intervention (and its successor, the 2012 “Stronger Futures in the Northern Territory” policy) was undertaken explicitly by the Commonwealth Government as a response to alleged criminal activity.  Evaluate the Intervention, including both immediate impacts on crime levels and Indigenous people’s interaction with the criminal justice system, and expected long-term impacts from aspects of the policy which (arguably) reimpose colonial practices. You will receive written feedback within two weeks of submission. This is the final assessment for the course.

System","description":"

All anglo-western criminal justice systems have significant over-representation, at all levels, of people with mental health disorders and cognitive disability. This course explores the life-pathways persons with these disabilities take into the criminal justice system and into prison in particular; examines the institutional contributions to these persons' offending and enmeshment in the system; analyses policy and legislation governing this area; applies critical criminology and critical disability theoretical perspectives to the area; and debates alternative understandings and frameworks.

Crime and justice issues dominate politics, the media and popular culture. This course looks critically at the development and nature of 'law and order politics' and the media's fascination with crime, both of which govern popular understandings of crime risks and threats, and appropriate policy responses to them. We consider how and why crime and justice have become such a source of fascination and a policy area on which elections can be won, with reference to numerous examples from contemporary politics, news media and popular culture.

of Law and Justice","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CRIM2036 - Prison and Punishment: Introduction to Penology","description":"

Subject Area: Criminology


This course provides an introduction to penology. It begins by considering the growing use of prisons across the developed world and is then constructed around three main themes: theorising the prison; perspectives for reform; and contemporary issues in Australian penal policy. The elective is designed to give students some insight into the frameworks used by social theorists to analyse imprisonment, with a view to examining contemporary issues such as ‘supermax’ prisons, deaths in custody, immigration detention, the civil rights of prisoners and prison privatisation. The experience of the New South Wales prison system following the 1978 Royal Commission into New South Wales prisons provides an immediate context for studying such issues and an opportunity to examine the complexities and limitations of prison reform.
The course intends to focus on the wider sociological implications of imprisonment and to introduce students to the various perspectives on punishment and the prison system offered by social theorists. It is designed to encourage both a basic understanding of the core literature and the ability to apply different penological perspectives to original research.


A student who has successfully completed this course should be able to:
understand some of the main themes within penology; understand the relationship of penology to criminology; appreciate the wider instrumental role of the prison in the criminal justice process; and contribute to more informed policy debate about prisons and punishment.

In this course you will be introduced to a theoretical and policy-oriented consideration of how and why we punish criminal offending, particularly through the use of imprisonment. You will take an inter-disciplinary approach utilising law, history, sociology, and criminology. You will consider various theoretical contributions that have shaped our understanding of punishment including the work of Durkheim, Foucault, Weber, Marxist approaches, and David Garland. Finally, you will also examine contemporary law and public policy issues, including juvenile detention, women in prison, the imprisonment of ethnic and racial minorities, inequality and imprisonment, privatisation, torture, deaths in custody, the death penalty, and the impact of law and order policies on punishment.

contentlets.description: In this course you will be introduced to a theoretical and policy-oriented consideration of how and why we punish criminal offending, particularly through the use of imprisonment. You will take an inter-disciplinary approach utilising law, history, sociology, and criminology. You will consider various theoretical contributions that have shaped our understanding of punishment including the work of Durkheim, Foucault, Weber, Marxist approaches, and David Garland. Finally, you will also examine contemporary law and public policy issues, including juvenile detention, women in prison, the imprisonment of ethnic and racial minorities, inequality and imprisonment, privatisation, torture, deaths in custody, the death penalty, and the impact of law and order policies on punishment.
contentlets.title: Explaining Punishment

In this course you will develop a critical understanding of the juvenile justice system, as well as the interdisciplinary perspectives on how young people become involved in antisocial behaviour and offending. You will critically analyse the legal avenues for dealing with young offenders, including the historical development of juvenile justice and current issues related to surveillance, diversion and detention in juvenile justice. Furthermore you will become familiar with effective prevention and intervention programs or strategies.

You will be required to appraise the research evidence and provide critical comment on possible prevention/interventions strategies that follow from this evidence. Feedback within 10 working days.

contentlets.description: In this course you will develop a critical understanding of the juvenile justice system, as well as the interdisciplinary perspectives on how young people become involved in antisocial behaviour and offending. You will critically analyse the legal avenues for dealing with young offenders, including the historical development of juvenile justice and current issues related to surveillance, diversion and detention in juvenile justice. Furthermore you will become familiar with effective prevention and intervention programs or strategies.

This course examines organised crime and criminal networks across a number of contexts including drug trafficking, terrorism, and the trade in illicit commodities. During the course we examine critical issues in the field including the debate about whether criminal groups are marked by structure/hierarchy or by flexibility/loose connections. We will also examine the use of Social Network Analysis by law enforcement agencies and researchers to better understand and respond to criminal networks. We will explore the utility of a "networked" perspective within criminology more generally (e.g., to explain trends in neighbourhood crime rates, gang crime). During the course, you will have the opportunity to conduct a case study on a criminal network.

Online exam- of 20 MCQ- that will test your theoretical knowledge of organised crime and criminal groups.
The test will be made available on the Moodle web page (i.e. an online exam). The time limit on the MCQ test means that the exam should not be attempted "open book" with reference material nearby. The time limit will provide ample opportunity for you to read and answer all the MCQs.

Students will receive their marks within ten days of submission.

You will receive written feedback and a numerical grade within two weeks of submission. You will be provided with the marking rubric at the start of the course so that you can work towards specified standards

Crime and Punishment in Historical Perspective","description":"

This course examines the history of criminal justice systems from the eighteenth to the twentieth century. Using case studies drawn from America, Europe, Australia and elsewhere, this course examines the development of the major institutions of criminal justice, including police, courts, and prison systems, and scholarly and historical debates about the approaches of the state in dealing with crime. It examines system changes such as the origins of the police force, the introduction of the adversarial criminal trial, the decline of capital punishment, and the increasing influence of the psychological sciences. The course asks you to reflect on the different outcomes of these global developments for diverse populations and in different national contexts.

What causes crime? Who is more likely to offend and why? What can we do to prevent crime? How does criminological theory help us understand the current criminal justice system? This course builds upon your understanding of the major theoretical approaches to crime and criminal justice, and seeks to answer the above questions. Criminological theory will be critically examined for its utility in developing policy responses and understanding the historical and contemporary development of our understandings of crime, criminality and the criminal justice system. Similar to other social sciences, criminology is a reflexive discipline whereby part of the criminological enterprise is to critically examine criminology itself. We will look at theories that help us to understand what generates crime, how to prevent crime and how crime is best dealt with.

contentlets.description: What causes crime? Who is more likely to offend and why? What can we do to prevent crime? How does criminological theory help us understand the current criminal justice system? This course builds upon your understanding of the major theoretical approaches to crime and criminal justice, and seeks to answer the above questions. Criminological theory will be critically examined for its utility in developing policy responses and understanding the historical and contemporary development of our understandings of crime, criminality and the criminal justice system. Similar to other social sciences, criminology is a reflexive discipline whereby part of the criminological enterprise is to critically examine criminology itself. We will look at theories that help us to understand what generates crime, how to prevent crime and how crime is best dealt with.

This capstone course draws together key concepts, themes and debates in criminology and encourages the application of these to current issues. By the end of the course you will have a portfolio of knowledge concerning eight current themes within criminology, and a specific knowledge base of one particular topic of interest. Presentation skills will be strengthened and the ability to synthesis and critically review research will be tested. Through focusing on the identification of current issues, as well as mapping the scope, strengths and critique of crime and justice problems, you will gain an understanding of the work of criminologists in the real world.

This task requires students to provide a 500 word overview of their proposed project (assessment 3).

Written feedback and a numerical grade will be given to students within 2 weeks of delivery. Marking criteria will be make available to students at the start of the semester so that they can work to specified standards.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"27874d37db791c50eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fb874d37db791c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f874d37db791c50eb6b147a3a961938","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"55","description":"

2000 words project submission. Final assessment for the course. This task is designed to get students thinking about what it might be like to work in an environment where they apply their skills and knowledge in order to approach a particular area of interest or concern. This may be a research priority area for a range of government agencies or a ‘special project’ to address a local crime issue

Written feedback and a numerical grade will be given to students within 2 weeks of delivery. Marking criteria will be make available to students at the start of the semester so that they can work to specified standards.

This task requires students to prepare a (2 page) Curriculum Vitae and responses to a set of selection criteria for a specific job (variable word length). This task is designed to make students reflect upon and detail their skills and knowledge for use beyond their university studies.

Written feedback and a numerical grade will be given to students within 2 weeks of delivery. Marking criteria will be make available to students at the start of the semester so that they can work to specified standards.

Crime Prevention Policy","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2021/JURD7503","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"JURD7503","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Law and Justice","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CRIM3011 - Crime Prevention Policy","description":"

In this course you will map the evolution and adoption of crime prevention policy both within Australia and internationally in the context of broader social policy and shifting political landscapes. You will gain critical insight into the theory that underpins social and situational crime prevention as well as criminal justice interventions. You will also explore the challenges and benefits of crime prevention through application of theory in real world scenarios. Throughout the course consideration is given to the limited impact of crime prevention policy on complex criminal and social justice priorities such as Aboriginal over-representation in the criminal justice system and violence against women.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CRIM3012 - Violence and Victimisation","description":"

In this course you will critically analyse crime prevention strategies and criminal justice responses to violent crime. You will take account of policy and legislative issues nationally and internationally, and address wider issues of risk assessment, offender treatment and victim support in dealing with violent crime. You will question the relationship between crime prevention, risk assessments strategies and treatment for violent offenders and evaluate support services and criminal justice responses towards victims of crime. To do so you will draw on case studies about serious violent crime including homicide, sexual offences, and armed robbery, and take a multi-disciplinary approach to understand the diverse needs and challenges in preventing and responding to personal violence.

State Crime and Human Rights","description":"

This module draws on some of the material previously taught in the criminology elective Crime, Power and Human Rights (CRIM 2018). It provides an overview of the criminological debates about state crime as a means of discussing some of the wider concerns of critical criminology. The course introduces students to some of the issues associated with the establishment of an international system of criminal justice. It also introduces students to some of the contemporary research being undertaken by criminologists into organised human rights abuses committed by states. Topics covered include: war crimes; modern and colonial genocide; immigration detention; torture and rendition; natural distaster as state crime; the International Criminal Court and resistance to state crime.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f0a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a96194f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Book Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students must compose a 1200 word book review of one of the following works:

Alex Alvarez (2001), Governments, Citizens and Genocide
Hannah Arendt (1994) Eichmann in Jerusalem
William Chambliss et al (eds) (2010), State Crime in the Global Age
Stanley Cohen (2001), States of Denial
Michael Grewcock (2009), Border Crimes
Richard Jackson et al (2010) Contemporary State Terrorism
Elizabeth Stanley (2009) Torture, Truth and Justice
Elizabeth Stanley and Jude McCulloch (eds) (2012) State Crime and Resistance
Eyal Weizman (2012) The Least of All Possible Evils.

The main aims of this assignment are to ensure students read some of the key texts in this field; to assess the extent to which students have understood the main concepts introduced during the first half of the course; and to provide students with a firm theoretical grounding for the major form assessment, the research essay. The review
should summarise the main themes of the book they have read and engage in some discussion about how such themes relate to the topics discussed in class. As a model for how to write a review, students are encouraged to read the reviews section of a recent issue of one of criminology journals from a provided list.

The assignment will be marked according to the following criteria:

  • A clear understanding of the contents of the book
  • Understanding of relevant concepts
  • Depth of analysis
  • Clarity of writing
  • Accuracy of referencing
  • Originality of content

 


","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a8a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e4a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ca7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a961925","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

All students are required to write a 3,500 research essay chosen from a list of provided topics. The essay is required to be properly referenced using a Harvard (in-text) system and a full bibliography must be attached. Students are encouraged to model their essay style on an article for an academic criminology journal, and will need to include a 150 word abstract with their essay.

The essay will be marked according to the following criteria:

  • Originality of content
  • Depth of analysis
  • The degree of critical thinking
  • Clarity and accuracy of writing
  • Evidence of planning
  • Accuracy of referencing

 


Individual consultations will be available throughout the session; potential essay themes will be discussed throughout the course; synopses and class presentations are designed to make this an inter-active ongoing process throughout the course - not just 2 weeks before the essay is due.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"20a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6ca7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a8a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e0a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e4a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"54a7cd37db791c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Class participation is an essential element of this course and is the most effective means by which students can gain ongoing feedback about their questions, ideas and progress in the course. The following criteria will be used to assess class performance and are a guide to how to contribute usefully to class discussion:

  • degree of evident preparation and completion of the required reading;
  • satisfactory completion of class exercises
  • constructive participation in allocated group discussions and class;
  • willingness and ability to contribute usefully to class discussion;
  • ability to synthesise and summarise previous contributions;
  • ability to reflect critically on the course materials and previous class discussion;
  • ability to formulate responses in clear and succinct terms;
  • ability to raise pertinent and thoughtful questions; and
  • compliance with 80 percent attendance requirement.

This course is designed to encourage students to think critically and creatively about topics that pose considerable challenges for conventional criminology. In this context, evidence of reading will go a considerable way to achieving a good class performance mark. All students are expected to be familiar with the reading for each class.

Effective class discussion and participation also requires consistent attendance. Attendance will be recorded and students are reminded of the University requirement to attend at least 80 percent of classes. Failure to attend classes may lead to a mark of zero for class participation and a refusal to permit students to submit written work for assessment.


Class participation is an established tool used by the Law faculty to facilitate an inter-active seminar teaching process. Feedback takes the form of a continuous dialogue with the student. A provisional CP mark is issued at the end of week 6.

contentlets.description: This module draws on some of the material previously taught in the criminology elective Crime, Power and Human Rights (CRIM 2018). It provides an overview of the criminological debates about state crime as a means of discussing some of the wider concerns of critical criminology. The course introduces students to some of the issues associated with the establishment of an international system of criminal justice. It also introduces students to some of the contemporary research being undertaken by criminologists into organised human rights abuses committed by states. Topics covered include: war crimes; modern and colonial genocide; immigration detention; torture and rendition; natural distaster as state crime; the International Criminal Court and resistance to state crime.
contentlets.title: State Crime and Human Rights

of Law and Justice","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CRIM3017 - Cybercrime","description":"

‘Cybercrime’ examines how the online world has borne new crimes and law enforcement responses, as well as investigates how the computer has become both a target of attack and a tool for criminal activity. This course explores a number of emerging cybercrimes (cyber-stalking, hacking, and attacks to critical infrastructure), and also explores how old crimes are affected in new mediums (organised crime, electronic theft, pornography, child abuse materials, and peer-to-peer filesharing systems). How do nation-states regulate criminal activity of those persons and organizations located abroad? How is law enforcement shifting from traditional mechanisms to new regulatory regimes and technological solutions? Additional topics include cyber-terrorism, ‘hactivism’, information warfare, and digital forensics. A technical background is not essential.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3c1ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a961930","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Note and Queries","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Notes and Queries are designed to allow students to engage the materials early on in the course and act as a motivation to carefully read the course materials.  Students will complete three 350 word reflective notes based on a set reading and media coverage of that topic. They will be uploaded to the course website by the Sunday night before the next class, and will be used to guide the class.  This will give students an early assessment of their skills to better help them with their eventual research essays.


Marked papers with comments provided to students.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2c1ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"301ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"681ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e81ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ec1ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"141ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Socratic Dialogue","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be require to complete a Socratic Dialogue outlining key elements of debate on one particular element of a specific cybercrime (e.g. fraud through phishing attacks). A number of topics will be suggested but each student may write on their choice of topic, however the topic must be approved by the Lecturer.

\n

The chosen topic will be explored in depth from two different perspectives. This assessment style resembles an essay in that students will be expected to form a thesis statement, master a topic, and write logically. It differs in that students will be required to approach the problem using two perspectives. A Socratic Dialogue has been chosen over an essay because it is extremely difficult to plagiarise this style of assessment.


Marked papers with comments provided to students.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"681ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b41ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ec1ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f01ed627dbb99850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"901e9627dbb99850eb6b147a3a9619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Class participation in class and online is encouraged but will graded.  Students will be expected to work 1 hour online each week.  Links to content will be posted, along with online problems for students to explore.

In this course you will examine victims' rights and victimology as emerging areas of criminological theory and practice. Victimology, as a distinct discipline of criminology focused on the subjectivity and agency of the victim of crime, will phrase an inquiry into the various means by which victims are now accorded some role within the criminal justice system. The emerging significance of the victim will be assessed through the various programs now calling for the participation of the victim as relevant subjects of law and justice. These include frameworks of victims' rights, victims' compensation and the inclusion of victims in sentencing.

Class Participation
\nA provisional class participation mark will be given at the end of week 4. The provisional mark gives students some indication of progress in class and provides the basis for discussions with the convenor over any issues of concern. A final class participation mark will be given at the end of term.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2730e577db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6330e577db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1330e577db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Research Essay (3000 words)
Detailed written comments will be made for each essay as part of the final assessment. Students are encouraged to discuss the progress of the essay with the convenor prior to the essay being lodged. This is the final assessment for this course.

Students will provide a synopsis of a proposed essay question (500 words) developed out of course readings and research and may expand upon one or more of the topics discussed in class. Students will provide a list of at least 5 scholarly readings to support their question.

Restorative Justice","description":"

Explores the theory and practice of restorative justice; that is, conflict resolution that involve victims, offenders and communities in a joint decision-making process rather than traditional legal and court-based responses. Assesses the strengths and limitations of restorative justice, and examines its application in a variety of settings from youth justice conferencing to in-prison restorative programs, to indigenous circle sentencing, to school and workplace bullying and to the global arena.

In this course you will examine the conduct of criminal trials in Australia and other countries. Through court observations and comparative study, you will build a comprehensive understanding of the particular features of the trial in Australian jurisdictions. You will critically evaluate criminal justice and trial processes in other countries by focusing on a number of themes including: different trial processes; a comparison of the Australian, US, French, Chinese and Japanese criminal justice systems; juries; judges; the fair trial; child defendants; vulnerable witnesses; victims' rights; sexual assault trials; and law reform.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"46a70177db791c50eb6b147a3a96195a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students are required to submit a (max) 2,500 word research essay, with a choice of two broad topics. Details will be provided in class but the choice is between: 
1. Justice Delivered? 'Miscarriage' option: This option is based on Alexander Volokh’s essay at http://www2.law.ucla.edu/volokh/guilty.htm#10. This essay must link to particular themes discussed in the course. 

 2. Court Fieldwork Essay
This essay topic should fit within the following framework:
From your fieldwork observations of criminal court practice discuss aspects of the practice/s you have witnessed and compare and contrast those practices with how they might differ in another country or style of justice system.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0ea70177db791c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4aa70177db791c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21a70177db791c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Participation in seminar discussion is assessed against specified standards communicated to students in advance. Students have the opportunity to meet with course convenor to discuss participation throughout Term. 

Students will receive verbal feedback and class participation marks via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"82a70177db791c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cea70177db791c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79a70177db791c50eb6b147a3a96193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Court fieldwork questionnaire","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to complete a fieldwork questionnaire detailing their analysis of court cases via moodle (500 words). 

Feedback is provided via moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"82a70177db791c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b1a70177db791c50eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective note","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students must provide one reflective note of between 800-1000 words, choosing from one class during the Term. Reflective notes ask you for your own perspective on topics. They are not about being well-researched, but instead, about being thoughtful (or reflective!). In this course your reflective note must take a particular style - it MUST connect readings and/or classroom discussion with your own choice of an additional dimension from the broad themes relevant to this course. It may be about dysfunctionality, an individual dimension, for example, relating to disadvantage or vulnerability, procedural injustice, social justice. Its role is to add your own thoughts about an issue from the class by stretching/applying it into a new context. Suggested ways of connecting the readings and discussion with the additional dimension (or broader theme) include linking your reflections on the readings and class discussion to:

  • current issues in the news (policy, law reform development, trials, media reporting etc), 
  • fiction
  • readings or discussion in other classes or courses
  • a theoretical perspective
  • your fieldwork experiences. 

You might choose Black Lives Matter, another country (Russia, China, Hong Kong). It doesn’t matter whether your individual dimension is local or global, or whether it’s fact or fiction, from media, social media or a personal experience. It is strongly recommended that to enhance depth of reflection, students pick only one or two aspects of the class discussion or reading and not attempt to reflect across all the readings or all the topics of discussion. The reflective note must respond to an aspect of a class. It cannot be a topic that forms part of your final essay. The reflective note must be sent to Jill  Hunter before the next class, and it will be marked asap.

Prisoners, community-based offenders, and other detainee groups exert huge, social, health and economic impacts on the community and pose significant challenges for society. Those in contact with the justice system endure some of the worst health outcomes in the community in terms of mental illness, substance misuse, traumatic brain injury and infectious diseases (e.g. HIV and viral hepatitis). Many of these can be attributed to the social determinants of health and lifestyle factors including injecting drug use, alcohol abuse, sexual risk behaviours, body piercing, tattooing and violence. Contact with the justice system, including incarceration, presents an important opportunity to intervene and improve health outcomes of hard-to-access populations.


Significant overlap exists between public health and criminology in terms of offender rehabilitation as the criminogenic needs of this population are also public health priorities that operate in a complex legal, human rights, research, and policy environment.


In this course you will learn about the complex health needs of those in contact with the justice system and the importance of these for offender rehabilitation. Experts in this field (e.g. a former prisoner, prison administrator, prison doctor and prisoner support worker) will present and discuss the challenges and controversies in prisoner and offender health (e.g. harm reduction strategies in prison, treatment of the mentally ill in the justice system), researching offenders, ethical dilemmas, health service delivery in prison, and prevention and intervention strategies. A visit to a prison will provide an opportunity to reflect on some of these issues.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9465b03adb50b410be4672f5f3961985","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Public health policy brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will write a 2000-word policy brief on a public health issue in Australia affecting prison populations (e.g. mental health, substance use, or infectious diseases). A list of eligible topics will be provided to students, based on the lectures. The student will be asked to adopt the persona of an intern for the Department of Justice and Attorney-General who has been asked to prepare a briefing paper to a Minister on a policy response to the chosen public health issue. The student should critically examine the evidence to inform the policy response. Students will receive written feedback and a numerical grade within two weeks of submission. The feedback sheet/rubric will be available to students so that they can work towards specified standards.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5065b03adb50b410be4672f5f3961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5465b03adb50b410be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5c65b03adb50b410be4672f5f3961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5c65b03adb50b410be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1465b03adb50b410be4672f5f396198a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Student to write a reflection (800-1000 words) on their learning about a topic of their choice covered in Week 1-5 of the course. Students will reflect on the effect of their learning on themselves and their future work/profession. Students will receive written feedback and a numerical grade two weeks following submission. The feedback sheet/rubric will be available to students so that they can work towards specified standards.

\n

 

\n

Students will participate in a class debate on key, contentious offender health issues. Topics and debate groups will be allocated by course convenors. Students will receive written feedback and a numerical grade two weeks following submission. The feedback sheet/rubric will be available to students so that they can work towards specified standards.

Drug Law and Policy","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/LAWS3427","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"LAWS3427","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Law and Justice","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CRIM3024 - Issues in Drug Policy","description":"

In Issues in Drug Policy (CRIM3024) you will take a multi-disciplinary approach in the examination of Australian and international drug laws and policies, drawing on a wide range of historical, socio-legal, political and criminological research.  In part one you will focus on the historical process of criminalisation of drugs, with specific emphasis on the role played by the United States and the United Nations in the prohibition movement. In part two you will examine the consequences of drug prohibition with a focus on social justice issues. In part three you will examine harm reduction policies, law reform and alternative approaches to criminalisation. Main topics you will investigate throughout the course include: the history of Australian drug laws; criminalisation of drugs and the international prohibitionist regime; Australian drug offences; intersectionality of drug laws with other areas of law; issues of social justice concerning prisoners, public health, and drug addiction; and, alternatives to the criminal law for dealing with drug use and addiction.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a3a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961957","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay (2500 words)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Students submit a 2500 word research essay on a topic of their choosing. The essay should make comprehensive use of the principal sources relevant to the topic and identify central issues calling for resolution.

Feedback includes formative feedback and the use of a rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2fa74177db791c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a3a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a7a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"efa74177db791c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Synopsis (500 words)","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The research essay is the major component of this course. In order to facilitate proper planning of the essay and to give students an opportunity to receive feedback on their ideas about the essay, students are required to submit a synopsis of not more than 500 words. The synopsis must set out the proposed essay question and an outline of how the student will go about answering it. The essay question needs to be developed out of the student’s own reading and research and may expand upon one of the classes (including those presented by guest lecturers) in Issues in Drug Policy.

This assessment is aimed toward providing feedback to students at an early stage

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2fa74177db791c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a3a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a7a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"efa74177db791c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"93a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a96193a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Participation in seminar discussion is assessed against specified standards communicated to students in advance. Students have the opportunity to meet with their teacher to discuss participation throughout semester.

Feedback includes formative feedback, feedback in class, and the use of a rubric.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2fa74177db791c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6ba74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a3a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a7a74177db791c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dba74177db791c50eb6b147a3a96190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Notes","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are required to submit 3 reflective notes at different points in the semester. Each reflective note is to be approximately 350 words long (5 marks each). As the name suggests, it is to be the student's own reflection on the readings and class discussion for that topic. No further reading is required beyond the assigned readings and the reflection is intended to be entirely the students' own, requiring no footnoting or supporting references. There is no requirement for referencing, or adoption of a particular academic style of writing. The aim is for the student to convey their own personal engagement on class discussions or learning areas to demonstrate their own learning process.

Feedback includes formative feedback, peer feedback in class, online and the use of a rubric.

contentlets.description: In Issues in Drug Policy (CRIM3024) you will take a multi-disciplinary approach in the examination of Australian and international drug laws and policies, drawing on a wide range of historical, socio-legal, political and criminological research.  In part one you will focus on the historical process of criminalisation of drugs, with specific emphasis on the role played by the United States and the United Nations in the prohibition movement. In part two you will examine the consequences of drug prohibition with a focus on social justice issues. In part three you will examine harm reduction policies, law reform and alternative approaches to criminalisation. Main topics you will investigate throughout the course include: the history of Australian drug laws; criminalisation of drugs and the international prohibitionist regime; Australian drug offences; intersectionality of drug laws with other areas of law; issues of social justice concerning prisoners, public health, and drug addiction; and, alternatives to the criminal law for dealing with drug use and addiction.
contentlets.title: Issues in Drug Policy

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CRIM3025 - Criminology Work Integrated Learning Placement","description":"

This course provides you with the unique opportunity to gain practical experience and deeper understanding of the criminal justice and related agencies. Aligned with UNSW’s emphasis on work-integrated learning, this course is a structured and supported work placement designed to give you practical experience in tackling criminal justice challenges through working with an criminal justice/related government or non-government organisation. This will be a one-of a kind experience to help you understand how criminal justice works in practice.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Criminology and Criminal Justice Program (BCCJ) and students enrolled in the Criminology Major in the Bachelor of Arts (BA). Enrolment is by course authority and is subject to a selection process involving a written submission and interview. To be eligible to apply, you must:


  • have a minimum WAM of 75;
  • have completed a minimum of 96 UOC overall including CRIM1010, CRIM1011, and CRIM2042
  • be in good academic standing.

 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"585825bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961988","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Placement Organisation Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students write a report (1500 words) on the host organisation and its role in the community, as well as the challenges/ politics of the space it operates within. Written feedback and a numerical grade will be provided within ten working days of submission.  Students will be assessed based on a rubric made available to them at the start of the course so they can work towards specified standards.  

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"445825bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"905825bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"045825bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Placement Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This task requires students to synthesise and critically reflect upon knowledge and experiences gained over the course of their placement and produce a report documenting key learning and how it relates to their program of study (2000 words total).  Written feedback is provided within ten days of submission. A numerical grade is based on a rubric made available to students at the start of the course so that they can work towards specified standards.

Enrolment in this course requires permission from the course convenor.


This course provides the opportunity to produce an original piece of research on a criminological topic of your choice. Across the term, you will be mentored by an academic supervisor to develop your research topic and questions, undertake research, and develop a 12,000 word thesis. This course assists students to develop and refine their skills in conducting independent research, and is ideal for those considering a PhD.

contentlets.description:
Enrolment in this course requires permission from the course convenor.

This course provides the opportunity to produce an original piece of research on a criminological topic of your choice. Across the term, you will be mentored by an academic supervisor to develop your research topic and questions, undertake research, and develop a 12,000 word thesis. This course assists students to develop and refine their skills in conducting independent research, and is ideal for those considering a PhD.
contentlets.title: Criminal Justice Research Thesis
